displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. You remember when you did all that biopsy there. Right in this area, right here. Doctor: So, that tells me that the cancer is growing in there primarily. Patient: Mmm…hmmm. Doctor: Which may mean I’d have to do radiation to that area. Patient: Wowwww. Okay. Doctor: Because that is a joint that we have to put our weight on Patient: Right. Doctor: When you walk, how can you walk otherwise? Patient: Exactly. Doctor: And, you know, so that is a critical area that we may need to Patient: Okay. Doctor: do radiation to sort of help control it while we are planning for all of this other stuff.

Patient: Push, just push Doctor: Yes. Pull up towards me. (Paper rattling and thumping) Patient: Yeah, no, like I said, at work, I don’t have any problem with walking around, but since, I say, I noticed that I was gettin’ that pain, and it was startin’ to become an irritant to me where I used to didn’t have that problem. You know? Doctor: Now, are you using anything for pain? Patient: No. I didn’t want to do that until I talked to you. Doctor: Okay. Do you want me to give you a prescription? Patient: I could use some. I need that what’s it named renewed, too…my benazepril. Remember you renewed that blood pressure pain medicine for me? Doctor: Okay. Patient: I need that, too. I don’t have a primary care doctor right now. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’m ‘ppossed to, ‘pposed to go see one of the Wayne State guys next Thursday. Doctor: Yeah, because one day I’m gonna assign you somebody or something, and then your insurance changed? Patient: No, that one over there, I didn’t. That’s why I told them I didn’t want to come back over there no more.

Family Member 1: So you are going to put him on the docetaxel pill? Doctor: Right or you might get on just the regular IV. So the trial is not that you get both, but you're one or the other. Family Member 1: When will you know that? Doctor: Yeah, so this is where it gets complicated. I'm gonna have my research nurse M_____ come in, it's always the devils in the details. Family Member 1: Okay. Doctor: What's tight about this and what's goofy about it and we've already shared this with a company is that they almost want to be like, okay, we know everything about you. And then two weeks later, you have to start. So there's a time thing that's so compressed, that I even fear that you might even, you know, need another CAT scan, because they only want everything done in a two week window. So if that's the case, obviously, she'll time it out. But I defer to the research team to make sure that that's done correctly. And I've learned over the years to basically zip it because I say something they're like, “Yeah, no, you just botched up that schedule.” So I just stay out of it and let Melanie take over. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But most of the things we'll be measuring will be that area by your bladder that was squishing the kidney. So that's a big spot that we really want to keep an eye on. Then of course, bone stuff, but that's an area and you’d want to know that this stuff is shrinking. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Chemo is chemo. So, you know, like we talked about last time, whether it's the pill version or the IV, we always worry about hair loss, you know, tiredness, how it affects your liver numbers, that's measured by blood. We always worry about your white cells, red cells, platelets- Patient: Right, right. Doctor: -you know, all the words that make you you. But that's why you're here getting, you know= Family Member 1: Monitored.

Family Member: Like by the tenth. Doctor: And, then, we’re going to skip Dr. S_’s appointment on April sixteenth, and then we’ll just follow with me subsequently. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And, um, um, Patient: By then, I will have had my – Doctor: I think you can get your hormone shot. Patient: My hormone shot. Doctor: I don’t know if you – if you get a hormone shot in January and it’s six months, you won’t need another one until July. So, that April version will just be a PSA check and see how we’re doing Patient: Right. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And maybe some more discussion. Family Member: Because that will be at least his third hormone shot.

Patient: …has metastasized to a point where that it’s still chemically – t - it hasn’t landed anywhere in layman’s terms, my words. Doctor: Right, right, right. Family Member: Right, right. Patient: But now that we can see, that it’s actually, we can see evidence of it being somewhere – Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - is there some form of uh… chemotherapy that could be done to sort of target that lymph node or the lymph nodes as far as a you know a cure, you know? Doctor: Yeah. That’s a great question, and it seems and it makes intuitive sense to try to target something that you can see… Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - because up until this point we’ve been talking about you have an invisible cancer. Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: We know that it has recurred; we simply cannot see it or spot it or target that. Family Member: Uh hum.

Patient: It doesn’t add up. Family Member: It really doesn’t. It just doesn’t, so. Doctor: So, I forgot, I was actually gonna check that and I will, I forgot but I will do that. I have to figure out how to do that with the – either the operating room or the pathology department. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Maybe the operating room would be first to find out if – I can’t look up another patient’s record that doesn’t belong to me, - Patient: Right. Family Member: Right. Doctor: -but I can find out if somebody… Family Member: Was scheduled the same day or something. Doctor: But I assume that’s not the case, but I’ll just double check. Patient: Alright. Family Member: Okay. (sighs)

Family Member: On some of them. I would gradually reintroduce them if I was you. Doctor: Yes. I agree with you. Patient: And I also had a question about that proton treatment that they have in B___. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Um Doctor: Not ah truly applicable to you at this point. That’s great for if you were just newly diagnosed with your prostate cancer or if you have some specific area on your spine. You obviously just got the radiation to there but if you know you’re a baby, for example, and you had a really tiny spinal cord, and you have this cancer next to it, a proton would be the perfect treatment. For adults, it’s a little harder to know what is better than the standard. So you know you hope maybe if you got protons you wouldn’t have had so many side effects. That’s possible. But it’s not as mainstream I think as we’d like to see it. At some point now when they’re really up and running and more patients will get experience, we’ll probably get a better sense of that. But for now I think you’ve got the best treatment which was those three areas in the spine and then your pelvis. Family Member: But is this proton more precise than-? Doctor: It’s supposed to be but I think the question is you know for the extra twenty or thirty thousand dollars that it costs- Family Member: Um Hmm. Doctor: -is that truly better than what the regulation radiation is going to afford because it’s not the old time radiation. The radiation you got is still image guided. It’s still blocked off. So those studies are ongoing. And that’s why not every center and not every state has protons. Because the cost is just astronomical- Family Member: Really. Doctor: -and not every insurance company is really paying for it. And you don’t know if it’s better. So this issue comes around a lot because of prostate. So protons wanted to replace, you know, oh, and I going to save the bladder or anything else. And that data doesn’t show it to be better necessarily. So it’s a big fight between the radiation guys. They’re trying to figure that out themselves. Um, but I don’t know. I think it’s good technology. So I think if needed, if it was a really tough spot or really small area I think it’s reasonable. But you had many spots that the radiation had to go after so I’m not sure that much of an advantage would have been gained. Patient: Well this radiation I went through this time-

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so the thing that was the nuance when, uh, the nurse called you the other day? Patient: Uh huh? Doctor: Is what we have found is that people who are on the Xtandi or enzalutamide may have a better likelihood of responding to these medicines. Patient: Oh. I see. Doctor: So, where you don’t qualify for this study is you’re not on Xtandi now. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, for us to think about this trial as an option for you, we would have to restart the Xtandi – Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Check your PSA in a couple weeks and knowing that your ARV seven positive, it’s very likely that the PSA will still be higher. (Pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s different. It’s new. There is buzz out there, but the bottom line in prostate cancer is we don’t know how well these drugs work, if at all. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Oh. Doctor: Now one of the things that I also wanted to discuss with you was some um of the clinical trials that we’re doing. In other words, research studies – Patient: Uh huh. DOC - investigating new approaches which might not be approved for prostate cancer. Doctor: For prostate cancer. And one of the um trials that we’re doing, which we are quite excited about is this concept of using high doses of testosterone as a therapy for prostate cancer. Patient: As a therapy? Now testosterone feeds the cancer, correct? Doctor: Correct. I knew you’d say that. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So this is quite a paradoxical approach. Patient: Okay, good. Doctor: And it turns out that you’re absolutely right. We’ve known for a long time for about seventy years that testosterone can feed into your prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: However, we have recently discovered in the last three or four years that they can take a patient who has had low testosterone levels for a very long time they call that hormone-resistant prostate cancer or castration-resistant prostate cancer is another term Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We have shown that to be true in the laboratory both in cancer cells which are being grown in a plastic dish in the lab. Patient: Right. Doctor: In mostly mice that have prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In humans we have some preliminary data that this is true. We have not conclusively proven that. And there are clearly patients who do not respond to this therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now one question that patients always ask me is “Is it possible you know for the uh testosterone to make the cancer worse?” In other words, could it accelerate or stimulate or speed up the cancer? Patient: Uh huh. My thoughts also. Doctor: And you know that was one of the very first things we thought of when we were designing these trials for uh patients and the first trial of this approach started in around twenty thirteen. And so we’ve been doing this for three or four years now. And in our initial studies, fortunately we did not see any cases where prostate cancer appeared to accelerate. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So we basically saw one of three patterns. Patient: Uh huh.

Family Member: So we’re gonna go back on this? Doctor: Yeah I just have to check with M___ and make sure it’s all legit through the protocol. Um… Family Member: Okay. Doctor: …get you the, you know the pills if that’s the case and then we’re on our way. Patient: Mhmm. Okay. Good. Family Member: Sounds like a plan. Doctor: Okay. Anything else? Healthcare Professional: Nope, probably protocol. Doctor: Okay. Yep. Uh sit up here. Let me, let me start working on that. I’ll be right back because I want to know about the records. Family Member: Okay. Okay, thank you. Doctor: Yep, one second. Yep, you’re welcome.

Patient: Oh good, good. Doctor: Alien DNA. Patient: My doctor watches the alien shows (laughs) Family Member: That’s everyone. Does that make you feel better. Patient: Okay great, man. I feel great now. I just, I just took the survey “Do I trust my doctor?” I gotta go back and change it. Doctor: Oh, my lord. Doctor: I find it interesting because they, not about the alien part, but they tell you a lot of cool stuff about weird places on earth that you didn’t know about. You’re like, oh, that’s kind of a cool place over there in, you know, Bulgaria or something. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, your next appointment is, uh, let’s see here. Patient: I have an appointment January twenty fifth for a hormone shot. Doctor: And to see me also? Patient: I don’t have anything, uh, with you yet. Family Member: Are you sure?

Patient: But I’m gonna be eating and next time I come here… Doctor: Okay, good. Yeah. Patient: …I’m gonna have my weight is gonna grow back. Doctor: Alright. Good. I’m gonna hold you to it. Patient: And you know when I tell you something (laughs) Patient: You know that’s how it be doc you know that, you know that. Doctor: Okay so when did I last give you this uh medication? When are you going to go fill them? Patient: Well I’ll go downtown to y’all pharmacy. Doctor: When are you going? Patient: I guess I’ll go tomorrow. I got to go down on Wednesday, so I’m gonna do it Wednesday. Doctor: What are you going Wednesday for? Patient: I got to go for this right here. Doctor: For the radiation?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we need to uh see if the testosterone is not right then I need… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …to get that authorized. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Alright. Doctor: Alright so I don’t think anything else except we’ll wait and see. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we’ll be in touch once we know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: I mean I miss getting chiropractic treatments. I know I can’t do that anymore. Doctor: No. Doctor: Don’t even go there. Patient: Now, is your position the same on inversion now? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you want to do a nice gentle massage to get the muscles, no problem. I’m all for that. Patient: Okay. Yeah. Doctor: But, no (sound of crack) Patient: I don’t. Doctor: You don’t want to (sound of crack) Patient: I know, I know not all MDs Doctor: Yeah
